item.title: Learning Rust
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: One of my 2024 batch goals at Recurse is to learn Rust. How? work through three introductory Rust resources The Rust Book Rustlings Yet Another Rust Resource) implement a small project in Rust Public repos with solutions msyvr/rusty msyvr/rustlings msyvr/yarry Learning notes

item.title: Recurse Center
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: “The retreat where curious programmers recharge and grow” I first joined the Recurse community in the fall of 2021, then returned for a second batch in the summer of 2024. Recurse brands itself as the equivalent of a writers’ retreat - but for software engineers. Recursers work at the edge of their abilities to become dramatically better programmers during their batch, then never-graduate and join the 2000+ alumni community. What do Recurses do during their batches?

item.title: ARENA: AI alignment
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: ARENA @ RC 2024 During my second batch at RC, I joined a study group to cover the materials from Callum McDougall’s Alignment Research Engineer Accelerator aka ARENA program which is normally delivered by LISI: the London Initiative for Safe AI. notes coming soon! in the meanwhile, some of the resources I used… Recommended reading ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks Generative Adversarial Nets Attention is All You Need

item.title: README
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: Welcome to a new version of my site. In the past, I’ve used a few other platforms for (sporadically) posting my writing (see Medium and Substack Posts). I’m hoping that collecting everything in one place will lower the friction of posting, particularly small notes and reference links (see Etc). In the Recurse spirit, here’s my small contribution to learning generously. Site build Framework: Hugo Theme: LoveIt theme Custom CSS: /_override.scss Combo based on Régis’ excellent chronicle of his journey from software engineer to machine learning engineer, with detailed guidance for setting up a Hugo/LoveIt site here.

item.title: Machine learning fundamentals
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: Resources Backprop The paper that started it all: Letters to Nature: Learning representation by back-propagating errors (pdf) Batch norm How does batch normalization help optimization? (pdf) Model evaluation Evaluating Large Language Models Trained on Code Fine tuning models: domain-adaptive pre-training Continual Pre-training of Language Models Synthetic data Machine Learning for Synthetic Data Generation: A Review Cosmopedia: how to create large-scale synthetic data for pre-training Large Language Models Practice projects Karpathy: Micrograd karpathy/micrograd: A tiny scalar-valued autograd engine and a neural net library on top of it with PyTorch-like API (github)

item.title: Raytracer
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: During my first Recurse Center retreat in the fall of 2021, I worked on code craftsmanship and experimented with a variety of software engineering concepts. One tangent led me to writing a ray tracing engine. GPUs rule In the course of exploring photorealistic image generation for movies and games, I discovered that the practical execution of algorithms which simulate realistic (physics-based) illumination is made possible by phenomenal advances in dedicated hardware, supported by machine learning.

item.title: Medium and Substack (old) posts
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: In addition to research publications, I have a small collection of prior publicly-shared works on Medium and Substack. A few posts from each: Medium: msyvr Picture perfect: AI + medical imaging “Leave me in peace, Wizard.”: Notes on James Mickens’ talk at USENIX Security ‘18 Seeing withing: Magical imaging Substack: gaming aging Mainstreaming longevity: scaling biohacking Hedging bets on healthier aging

item.title: Mickens Usenix 2018
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: James Mickens on the value of skepticism Notes from James Mickens’ talk at USENIX Security ‘18. If you haven’t seen James’ talk and have an hour to view his actual keynote, please do yourself a favor and just go see his talk. It’s entertaining, educational, and thought provoking. Absolutely not to be missed - the most fun you’ll have while thinking about cybersecurity, machine learning, and computing more generally. Case in point, a fun still from his talk…

item.title: Picture Perfect: AI + Medical Imaging
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: Picture perfect: AI + medical imaging Caveat emptor! Written in November 2017. Progress in AI is astonishingly rapid: this is inevitably out of date. Radiology’s inevitable evolution Artificial intelligence (AI) in medical imaging is a controversial topic - up for debate are questions regarding its implementation (from both technical and regulatory standpoints), ultimate potential (presuming it has the theoretical potential to do better, will it do better in practice, and how might it alter clinical processes?

item.title: Seeing Within
item.author: Monica Spisar
item.description: Seeing within: Magical imaging Much of the complexity of the human body is shrouded in mystery. But we know a lot more than we used to about its structure and function. Structure (anatomy), in particular, has been mapped out in meticulous detail. In the distant past, building up static anatomical maps relied on information from dissections. Yeah, gross. Also, pretty much useless to a live person needing guidance for treatment of injury or disease, or for monitoring a chronic condition.
